Turing Award 1982

Winner: Stephen Cook

Stephen Cook, also knwon as the forefathers of the computational compelxity theory, was entitled of the Turing Award of 1982 thanks to the contributions he gave towards complexity theory.

Also, in 1971 Mr. Cook published a paper called "The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures" which has the foundations of the "NP-complete problems" theory; those are problems which cannot be solute by known algorithm.

Moreover, Cook also spent time expanding on Turing's concept of computability (what a machine cannot or can solve). Cook is also the author of the Millennium Problems, which arguments the security systems bearing the digital economy.

Cook hypothesizes that there are optimization problems that cannot be solved by efficient algorithms. A great deal of research in computational complexity theory has been spurred by this conjecture, allowing us to gain a deeper understanding of the inherent challenges of computational problems and how to approach them efficiently. Despite its openness, the conjecture is one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems.
